[This is] a Book revealed to you, [O Muhammad] - so let there not be in your breast distress therefrom - that you may warn thereby and as a reminder to the believers.
Follow, [O mankind], what has been revealed to you from your Lord and do not follow other than Him any allies. Little do you remember.
And how many cities have We destroyed, and Our punishment came to them at night or while they were sleeping at noon.
And their declaration when Our punishment came to them was only that they said, "Indeed, we were wrongdoers!"
Then We will surely question those to whom [a message] was sent, and We will surely question the messengers.

Indeed, at that time, Allah the Exalted will make true His saying: **"Then We will surely question those to whom messengers were sent, and We will surely question the messengers. Then We will surely relate [their deeds] to them with knowledge, and We were not absent."** (7:6-7) He, glorified is He, will begin with the Prophets, **"On the Day when Allah will assemble the messengers and say, 'What was the response you received?' They will say, 'We have no knowledge. Indeed, it is You who is Knower of the unseen.'"** (5:109) O, the severity of a day when the intellects [ʿuqūl] of the Prophets are bewildered and their knowledges [ʿulūm] are erased from the intensity of the awe [hayba], when it is said to them, "What response did you receive?"—and they had been sent to the creation and they had known—so their intellects [ʿuqūl] are confounded and they do not know with what to answer. So they say, from the intensity of the awe [hayba], "We have no knowledge [ʿilm]. Indeed, it is You who is Knower of the unseen [ʿallām al-ghuyūb]." And they, at that time, are truthful, for their intellects [ʿuqūl] have flown from them and their knowledges [ʿulūm] have been erased, until Allah the Exalted strengthens them. Then Noah, peace be upon him, will be called and it will be said to him, "Did you convey?" He will say, "Yes." Then it will be said to his nation, "Did it reach you?" They will say, "No warner came to us." And Jesus, peace be upon him, will be brought, and Allah the Exalted will say to him, "Did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as gods besides Allah'?" And he will remain writhing under the awe [hayba] of this question for years. O, the greatness of a day when the reckoning [siyāsa] is established upon the Prophets with a question like this.

Indeed, he said: "You created me from fire [nār] and created him from clay [ṭīn]." Therefore, since the accursed one did not prostrate to our father Adam—upon him be the prayers and peace of God—then he should not aspire to prostrate to his children. And whenever he [the heart] refrains from its whispering [waswās], its transgression [ʿudwān], its fluttering [ṭayrān], and its wandering [jawlān], then he has manifested his submission [inqiyād] and his compliance [idhʿān]. And his submission through compliance is a prostration [sujūd] from him; it is the spirit [rūḥ] of prostration. Indeed, know that God the Exalted has coupled gratitude [shukr] with remembrance [dhikr] in His Book, even though He said: "And the remembrance of God is greater." For He the Exalted said: "So remember Me; I will remember you. And be grateful to Me and do not deny Me." And He the Exalted said: "What would God do with your punishment if you are grateful and believe?" And He the Exalted said: "And We will reward the grateful." And He, Mighty and Majestic, informed about the accursed Iblis: "I will surely sit for them on Your straight path." It is said it is the path of gratitude [shukr], and due to the exalted rank of gratitude [shukr], the accursed one cast aspersions on creation, saying: "And you will not find most of them grateful [shakirin]." And He the Exalted said: "And few of My servants are grateful [shakur]." And God the Exalted has decreed increase with gratitude [shukr] without exception, for He the Exalted said: "If you are grateful, I will surely increase you." And He made exception in five things: in granting sufficiency, in answering, in provision, in forgiveness, and in repentance. For He the Exalted said: "Then God will provide for you from His bounty, if He wills." And He said: "He will remove that for which you supplicate Him, if He wills." And He said: "He provides for whom He wills without account." And He said: "And He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills." And He said: "And God turns in forgiveness to whom He wills." And it is a created attribute from the attributes of Lordship, for He the Exalted said: "And God is Appreciative [shakur] and Forbearing." And God has made gratitude [shukr] the key speech of the people of Paradise, for He the Exalted said: "And they will say, 'Praise to God, who has fulfilled for us His promise.'" And He said: "And their final call will be, 'Praise to God, Lord of the worlds.'" As for the narrations, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "The grateful eater is of the same rank as the patient faster." And it is narrated from 'Ata that he said: "I entered upon 'A'isha, may God be pleased with her, and said, 'Inform us of the most wondrous thing you saw from the Messenger of God, peace be upon him.' She wept and said, 'And which of his affairs was not wondrous? He came to me one night and entered the bed with me'—or she said, 'under my cover'—'until my skin touched his skin. Then he said, "O daughter of Abu Bakr, allow me to worship my Lord." I said, "I love your closeness, but I prefer your desire." So I gave him permission. He rose to a water-skin and performed ablution, not using much water. Then he stood to pray and wept until his tears flowed upon his chest. Then he bowed and wept. Then he prostrated and wept. Then he raised his head and wept. He continued like that, weeping, until Bilal came to give the call to prayer. I said, 'O Messenger of God, what makes you weep when God has forgiven your past and future sins?' He said, 'Should I not be a grateful servant [abdan shakuran]? And why should I not do that when God the Exalted has revealed to me, "Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth..."' the verse." This indicates that weeping should never cease, and to this secret points what is narrated: that one of the prophets passed by a small stone from which much water was flowing. He was amazed by it, so God the Exalted made it speak, and it said, 'Since...'"

a.g: [Allah] said, "Get out of Paradise, reproached and expelled. Whoever follows you among them - I will surely fill Hell with you, all together."
And "O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise and eat from wherever you will but do not approach this tree, lest you be among the wrongdoers."

But Satan whispered to them to make apparent to them that which was concealed from them of their private parts. He said, "Your Lord did not forbid you this tree except that you become angels or become of the immortal."
And he swore [by Allah] to them, "Indeed, I am to you from among the sincere advisors."

So he made them fall, through deception. And when they tasted of the tree, their private parts became apparent to them, and they began to fasten together over themselves from the leaves of Paradise. And their Lord called to them, "Did I not forbid you from that tree and tell you that Satan is to you a clear enemy?"

[Allah] said, "Descend, being to one another enemies. And for you on the earth is a place of settlement and enjoyment for a time."
He said, "Therein you will live, and therein you will die, and from it you will be brought forth."

O children of Adam, We have bestowed upon you clothing to conceal your private parts and as adornment. But the clothing of righteousness - that is best. That is from the signs of Allah that perhaps they will remember.

Vol1 book 1
O Children of Adam, We have sent down upon you a garment [libas] to cover your shameful parts [saw'at] — meaning knowledge [al-'ilm] — and adornment [risha] — meaning certainty [al-yaqin] — and the garment of God-consciousness [libas al-taqwa] — meaning modesty [al-haya'].

a.g: O children of Adam, let not Satan tempt you as he removed your parents from Paradise, stripping them of their clothing to show them their private parts. Indeed, he sees you, he and his tribe, from where you do not see them. Indeed, We have made the devils allies to those who do not believe.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 8a
Indeed, He, the Mighty and Majestic, says: "Indeed, he sees you, he and his tribe, from where you do not see them." And the Qur'an, from its beginning to its end, is a warning against Satan [Shaytan]. How then, when He has commanded caution against the enemy, just as He commanded caution against the disbelievers? For He, the Exalted, says: "And let them take their precaution and their weapons," and He, the Exalted, says: "And prepare against them whatever you are able of power and of steeds of war." So if it is incumbent upon you, by the command of Allah, to be cautious of the disbelieving enemy whom you see, then it is more fitting that it be incumbent upon you to be cautious of an enemy who sees you and you do not see him. And for this reason, Ibn Muhayriz said: "Prey that you see and does not see you, you are likely to overcome it; and prey that sees you and you do not see it, it is likely to overcome you." He was pointing to Satan [Shaytan]. So how, when heedlessness of the enmity of the disbeliever results only in killing, which is martyrdom [shahada], while neglecting caution against Satan [Shaytan] exposes one to the Fire [Nar] and the painful punishment? So, being occupied with Allah does not mean turning away from what Allah has warned against, and by this, the doctrine of the second group is invalidated in their assumption that this detracts from trust [tawakkul]. For taking up the shield and weapons, gathering troops, and digging the trench did not detract from the trust [tawakkul] of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. So how could fearing what Allah has warned against and being cautious of what He has commanded to be cautious of detract from trust [tawakkul]? And we have mentioned in the Book of Trust [Kitab al-Tawakkul] what clarifies the error of those who claim that the meaning of trust [tawakkul] is to completely abandon means [asbab]. And His saying, the Exalted, "And prepare against them whatever you are able of power and of steeds of war," does not contradict compliance with trust [tawakkul], as long as the heart [qalb] believes that the One who harms and benefits, the One who gives life and causes death, is Allah, the Exalted. Likewise, one is cautious of Satan [Shaytan] while believing that the One who guides and leads astray is Allah, and one sees the means [asbab] as subservient intermediaries—as we mentioned concerning trust [tawakkul].

a.g: And when they commit an immorality, they say, "We found our fathers doing it, and Allah has ordered us to do it." Say, "Indeed, Allah does not order immorality. Do you say about Allah that which you do not know?"

Say, [O Muhammad], "My Lord has ordered justice and that you maintain yourselves [in worship of Him] at every place [or time] of prostration, and invoke Him, sincere to Him in religion." Just as He originated you, you will return [to life] -
A group [of you] He guided, and a group deserved [to be in] error. Indeed, they had taken the devils as allies instead of Allah while they thought that they were guided.
O children of Adam, take your adornment at every masjid, and eat and drink, but be not excessive. Indeed, He likes not those who commit excess.

Indeed, to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: "And eat and drink, and do not be wasteful [la tusrifu]." And whenever a person does not feel hunger nor satiety, worship [al-'ibadah] and reflection [al-fikr] are made easy for him, and he becomes light in his soul [nafs] and strong for action despite his lightness. But this is after the temperament's moderation. a.g: Say, "Who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good [lawful] things of provision?" Say, "They are for those who believe during the worldly life [but] exclusively for them on the Day of Resurrection." Thus do We detail the verses for a people who know.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, it remains upon the foundation of permissibility [ibaha] by analogy [qiyas] to the sounds of birds and others. Rather, I say: listening to strings [al-awtar] from one who strikes them without a harmonious measure [wazn], even if pleasurable, is also forbidden [haram]. And by this, it becomes clear that the cause ['illa] for their prohibition is not merely the pleasant pleasure [ladhdha], for by analogy [qiyas], all good things [tayyibat] are permissible [tahlih] except what in its permissibility is corruption [fasad]. Allah the Exalted has said: "Say, 'Who has forbidden the adornment [zinah] of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good things [tayyibat] from the provision [rizq]?'" These sounds are not forbidden [tuharram] inasmuch as they are measured [mawzunah] sounds. They are only forbidden due to an incidental factor ['arid] as will come in the forbidden incidental factors [al-'awarid al-muharramah] of the third degree: the measured [al-mawzun] and the intelligible [al-mafhum], and that is poetry [shi'r]. And that does not emerge except from the throat [hanjarah] of a human. So it is decisively judged permissible [ibaha] for that, because it has only increased by being intelligible [mafhum]. And intelligible speech [al-kalam al-mafhum] is not forbidden, and the pleasant, measured [mawzun] sound is not forbidden. So if the individual components [al-ahad] are not forbidden, then from where would the combined whole [al-majmu'] be forbidden? Yes, one must look into what is understood [yufham] from it. For if there is in it a forbidden matter [amr mahzur], its prose [nathr] and its verse [nazm] are forbidden, and uttering it is forbidden whether it was with melodies [alhan] or not. And the truth [al-haqq] in it is what Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said when he said: "Poetry [shi'r] is speech [kalam]; its good is good and its bad is bad." And whenever it is permissible to recite poetry [inshad al-shi'r] without sound and melodies, it is permissible to recite it with melodies. For when permissible individual matters [al-mubahat] come together, that combined whole [majmu'] is permissible. And whenever a permissible thing [mubah] is joined to another permissible thing, it does not become forbidden except if the combined whole contains a forbidden element [mahzur] which the individual components do not contain. And there is no forbidden element here. And how can the recitation of poetry be denied when it was recited in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him?

So just as the dead are resurrected from their graves, likewise the sleepers are resurrected from their beds. Indeed, your Lord [Rabb] says: "Call upon your Lord [Rabb] in humility [tadarru'] and in secret [khufyah]; indeed, He does not love the transgressors [al-mu'tadin]." And He, the Exalted, says: "And your Lord [Rabb] says, 'Call upon Me; I will respond to you. Indeed, those who are too arrogant to worship Me will enter Hell in humiliation.'" And He, the Mighty and Majestic, says: "Say, 'Call upon Allah or call upon the Most Merciful [al-Rahman]; whichever you call upon, to Him belong the best names.'" And Nu'man ibn Bashir reported from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he said: "Indeed, supplication [du'a'] is worship [al-'ibadah]," then he recited: "Call upon Me; I will respond to you." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Supplication [al-du'a'] is the marrow of worship [al-'ibadah]." And Abu Hurayrah reported that he, peace be upon him, said: "There is nothing more honorable to Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, than supplication [al-du'a']." And he, peace be upon him, said: "The servant [al-'abd] is not missed by his supplication [du'a'] with one of three things: either a sin [dhamb] is forgiven for him, or a good [khayr] is hastened for him, or a good [khayr] is stored for him." And Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Enough for supplication [al-du'a'] with righteousness [al-birr] is what salt is enough for food." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Ask Allah, the Exalted, from His bounty [fadlihi], for indeed Allah, the Exalted, loves to be asked, and the best worship [al-'ibadah] is awaiting relief [al-faraj]." **(The Etiquettes of Supplication [Adab al-Du'a'])** They are ten: **The First:** That he seeks out for his supplication [du'a'] the noble times [al-awqat al-sharifah], such as the Day of 'Arafah from the year, and Ramadan from the months, and Friday from the week, and the time of the pre-dawn [al-sahar] from the hours of the night. Allah, the Exalted, says: "And in the hours before dawn [al-asahar] they would ask forgiveness [yastaghfirun]." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Allah, the Exalted, descends every night to the lowest heaven [sama' al-dunya] when the last third of the night remains, and He, the Mighty and Majestic, says: 'Who calls upon Me so that I may respond to him? Who asks of Me so that I may give him? Who seeks My forgiveness so that I may forgive him?'" And it is said that Ya'qub, peace be upon him, only said, "I will ask forgiveness for you from my Lord [Rabb]," so that he would supplicate at the time of the pre-dawn [waqt al-sahar]. And it is said that he stood at the time of the pre-dawn [waqt al-sahar] supplicating, and his sons were saying 'Ameen' behind him, so Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, revealed: "I have forgiven them and made them prophets." **The Second:** That he seizes the noble states [al-ahwal al-sharifah]. Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Indeed, the gates of heaven [abwab al-sama'] open when the ranks advance in the path of Allah [sabil Allah], and when rain descends, and when the prescribed prayers [al-salawat al-maktubah] are established, so seize supplication [al-du'a'] in them." And Mujahid said: "Indeed, the prayer [al-salah] has been placed in the best of hours, so upon you is supplication [al-du'a'] after the prayers." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Supplication [al-du'a'] between the call to prayer [al-adhan] and the commencement of prayer [al-iqamah] is not rejected." And he, peace be upon him, also said: "The supplication [da'wah] of the fasting person [al-sa'im] is not rejected." And in reality, the nobility of times [sharaf al-awqat] returns to the nobility of states [sharaf al-halat] as well.

a.g: And the good land - its vegetation emerges by permission of its Lord; but that which is bad - nothing emerges except sparsely, with difficulty. Thus do We diversify the signs for a people who are grateful.
We had certainly sent Noah to his people, and he said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a tremendous Day.
Said the eminent among his people, "Indeed, we see you in clear error."

I convey to you the messages of my Lord and advise you; and I know from Allah what you do not know.
Then do you wonder that there has come to you a reminder from your Lord through a man from among you, that he may warn you and that you may fear Allah so you might receive mercy."

So they were astonished that a human being like them should attain the rank of Messengership [risalah] and Revelation [wahy] and proximity [qurb] to God, the Exalted, so they envied them, and they desired the removal of Prophethood [nubuwwah] from them out of distress that one who is like them in creation should be preferred over them, not from an intention of arrogance [takabbur] and seeking leadership [riyasah] and advancing enmity or another cause from among all the causes. And they said, astonished, "Has God sent a human being as a messenger?" and they said, "Why were angels not sent down to us?" and God, the Exalted, said, "Or do you wonder that there has come to you a Reminder [dhikr] from your Lord upon a man from among you?" the verse.

a.g: But they denied him, so We saved him and those who were with him in the ship. And We drowned those who denied Our signs. Indeed, they were a blind people.

Said the eminent ones who disbelieved among his people, "Indeed, we see you in foolishness, and indeed, we think you are of the liars."
[Hud] said, "O my people, there is not foolishness in me, but I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds."

Said the eminent ones who were arrogant among his people to those who were oppressed - to those who believed among them, "Do you [actually] know that Salih is sent from his Lord?" They said, "Indeed we, in that with which he was sent, are believers."

And indeed, Allah the Exalted has described the liars [al-kadhibin] in their relation to the sincere advisors [al-nasihin], when He said: "But you do not love the sincere advisors." And this is regarding a fault of which the person is heedless [ghafil]. As for that which you know he is aware of within himself, then it is something he is compelled to by his innate nature [tabi'], so it is not fitting to expose his covering [sitr] if he conceals it. And if he makes it apparent, then there is no alternative but to be gentle in the advice [al-nasihah], by hinting [al-ta'rid] at times and by being explicit [al-tasrih] at others, to a degree that does not lead to alienation [al-ihash]. For if you know that the advice will have no effect upon him and that he is compelled by his innate nature [tabi'] to persist in it, then silence regarding it is more fitting.

a.g: And [We had sent] Lot when he said to his people, "Do you commit such immorality as no one has preceded you with from among the worlds?

But the answer of his people was only that they said, "Evict them from your city! Indeed, they are men who keep themselves pure."
So We saved him and his family, except for his wife; she was of those who remained [with the evildoers].
And We rained upon them a rain [of stones]. Then see how was the end of the criminals.

So the earthquake seized them, and they became within their home [corpses] fallen prone.
Those who denied Shu'ayb - it was as though they had never resided there. Those who denied Shu'ayb - it was they who were the losers.

Then We exchanged in place of the bad [condition], good, until they increased [and prospered] and said, "Our fathers [also] were touched with hardship and ease." So We seized them suddenly while they did not perceive.

And if only the people of the cities had believed and feared Allah, We would have opened upon them blessings from the heaven and the earth; but they denied [the messengers], so We seized them for what they were earning."
Then, did the people of the cities feel secure from Our punishment coming to them at night while they were asleep?
Or did the people of the cities feel secure from Our punishment coming to them in the morning while they were at play?
Then did they feel secure from the plan of Allah? But no one feels secure from the plan of Allah except the losing people.

Vol3 book 10a
Indeed, the word of the Almighty: **"Do they feel secure from the plan of Allah?"** [7:99]... So know that whoever takes spiritual knowledge [ma'rifa] from mere words and analogies, his stumbling will be frequent. And this example we give, though we present it, does not perfectly match our subject in every aspect. For the cause of overwhelming hope is knowledge [‘ilm] gained through experience: one knows through experience the soundness of the soil, its purity, the soundness of the seed, the soundness of the air, and the scarcity of destructive lightning strikes in those regions and others. The example for our matter, however, is a seed whose kind has never been tried, sown in a strange land the sower has not known or tested, in a country he does not know whether lightning is frequent or not. Such a sower, even if he exerts his utmost effort and brings forth all his capability, his hope [raja’] will not overcome his fear [khawf]. And the seed in our matter is faith [iman]; the conditions for its soundness are subtle. The earth is the heart [qalb], and its hidden recesses are malignant; its purification from hidden polytheism [shirk], hypocrisy [nifaq], and ostentation [riya’] is obscure, and the hidden traits within it are ambiguous. The blights are the appetites [shahawat] and the glitter of the world [dunya], and the heart's inclination towards them in the future, even if it is safe in the present. This is something not verified or known through experience, for causes may appear that cannot be withstood, and their like has not been experienced. The lightning strikes are the terrors of the agonies of death and the disturbance of belief at that time—their like has not been experienced. Then the harvest and attainment are upon departure from the Resurrection to Paradise—that has not been experienced. Whoever knows the realities [haqa’iq] of these matters, if he is weak of heart, timid by nature, his fear will inevitably overcome his hope, as will be related in the states of the fearful among the Companions and the Successors. If he is strong of heart, firm of resolve, complete in knowledge [ma’rifa], his fear and hope become balanced. But as for his hope overcoming? No, never. Indeed, ‘Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, would intensely scrutinize his heart until he would ask Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him, if he recognized in him any traces of hypocrisy, since the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had specially entrusted him with the knowledge of the hypocrites. So who is it that can purify his heart from the hidden recesses of hypocrisy and concealed polytheism? And even if he believes his heart is pure from that, from where does he feel secure from the plan of Allah, the Exalted, in deluding him about his state and concealing his fault from him? And even if he is confident in that, from where is he confident of remaining upon that until the perfection of a good ending? For he, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, a man may perform the deeds of the people of Paradise for fifty years, until there remains between him and Paradise but a span," and in a narration: "but the measure of a camel's pause, then the decree overtakes him and he is sealed with the deed of the people of the Fire." And the measure of a camel's pause does not allow for a deed of the limbs; it is merely the measure of a fleeting thought that stirs in the heart at death, necessitating an evil ending. So how can one feel secure from that? Therefore, the utmost limit for the believer is that his fear and hope become balanced. The predominance of hope in most people is based on delusion and lack of true knowledge [ma’rifa]. For that reason, Allah, the Exalted, combined them in describing those He praised, saying: **"They supplicate their Lord in fear and eager hope"** [32:16], and the Almighty said: **"And they supplicate Us in hope and fear"** [21:90]. And where is the like of ‘Umar, may Allah be pleased with him? The people existing in this time—all of them—what is most wholesome for them is the predominance of fear, provided it does not lead them to despair [ya’s], abandoning works, and cutting off hope for forgiveness, for that would become a cause for laziness in work and an invitation to plunge into disobedience. That is despair, and it is not fear. Indeed, fear is that which spurs one to work, clouds all appetites, agitates the heart from reclining towards the world [dunya], and calls it to turn away from the abode of delusion. That is the praiseworthy fear, not the whisper of the soul which has no effect in restraint and urging, nor the despair that leads to hopelessness. And Yahya ibn Mu’adh said: "Whoever worships Allah with pure fear drowns in seas of anxious thoughts. Whoever worships Him with pure hope wanders lost in the desert of delusion. Whoever worships Him with fear and hope walks straight on the path of remembrance." And Makhul al-Dimashqi said: "Whoever worships Allah with fear is a Kharijite. Whoever worships Him with hope is a Murji’ite. Whoever worships Him with love is a heretic. Whoever worships Him with fear, hope, and love is a monotheist." Therefore, combining these matters is necessary. The predominance of fear is the most wholesome, but *before* drawing near to death. As for at the time of death, the most wholesome is the predominance of hope and good expectation, for fear runs the course of a whip that spurs to work, and the time for work has ended for the one drawing near to death.

If he is strong of heart, firm of resolve, complete in knowledge [ma’rifa], his fear and hope become balanced. But as for his hope overcoming? No, never. Indeed, ‘Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, would intensely scrutinize his heart until he would ask Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him, if he recognized in him any traces of hypocrisy, since the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had specially entrusted him with the knowledge of the hypocrites. So who is it that can purify his heart from the hidden recesses of hypocrisy and concealed polytheism? And even if he believes his heart is pure from that, from where does he feel secure from the plan of Allah, the Exalted, in deluding him about his state and concealing his fault from him? And even if he is confident in that, from where is he confident of remaining upon that until the perfection of a good ending? For he, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, a man may perform the deeds of the people of Paradise for fifty years, until there remains between him and Paradise but a span," and in a narration: "but the measure of a camel's pause, then the decree overtakes him and he is sealed with the deed of the people of the Fire." And the measure of a camel's pause does not allow for a deed of the limbs; it is merely the measure of a fleeting thought that stirs in the heart at death, necessitating an evil ending. So how can one feel secure from that? Therefore, the utmost limit for the believer is that his fear and hope become balanced. The predominance of hope in most people is based on delusion and lack of true knowledge [ma’rifa]. For that reason, Allah, the Exalted, combined them in describing those He praised, saying: **"They supplicate their Lord in fear and eager hope"** [32:16], and the Almighty said: **"And they supplicate Us in hope and fear"** [21:90]. And where is the like of ‘Umar, may Allah be pleased with him? The people existing in this time—all of them—what is most wholesome for them is the predominance of fear, provided it does not lead them to despair [ya’s], abandoning works, and cutting off hope for forgiveness, for that would become a cause for laziness in work and an invitation to plunge into disobedience. That is despair, and it is not fear. Indeed, fear is that which spurs one to work, clouds all appetites, agitates the heart from reclining towards the world [dunya], and calls it to turn away from the abode of delusion. That is the praiseworthy fear, not the whisper of the soul which has no effect in restraint and urging, nor the despair that leads to hopelessness. And Yahya ibn Mu’adh said: "Whoever worships Allah with pure fear drowns in seas of anxious thoughts. Whoever worships Him with pure hope wanders lost in the desert of delusion. Whoever worships Him with fear and hope walks straight on the path of remembrance." And Makhul al-Dimashqi said: "Whoever worships Allah with fear is a Kharijite. Whoever worships Him with hope is a Murji’ite. Whoever worships Him with love is a heretic. Whoever worships Him with fear, hope, and love is a monotheist." Therefore, combining these matters is necessary. The predominance of fear is the most wholesome, but *before* drawing near to death. As for at the time of death, the most wholesome is the predominance of hope and good expectation, for fear runs the course of a whip that spurs to work, and the time for work has ended for the one drawing near to death.

a.g: Has it not become clear to those who inherited the earth after its [previous] people that if We willed, We could afflict them for their sins? But We seal over their hearts so they do not hear.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j3 k01
Indeed, if We willed, We could strike them for their sins and seal [naṭbaʿu] their hearts [qulūb], so they would not hear. Thus, He linked the absence of hearing to the sealing [al-ṭabʿ] due to sins, just as He linked hearing to God-consciousness [taqwā], saying: And be conscious of God and listen, and be conscious of God, and God will teach you. Whenever sins accumulate, the heart [al-qalb] is sealed [yuṭbaʿu], and at that point the heart [al-qalb] becomes blind to perceiving the truth [al-ḥaqq] and the rectitude of religion [ṣalāḥ al-dīn], and it belittles the affair of the Hereafter [al-Ākhira], and its concern becomes confined solely to it. So when its hearing is struck by the command of the Hereafter [al-Ākhira] and what it contains of perils, it enters one ear and exits the other, and it does not settle in the heart [al-qalb], nor does it move it to repentance [tawba] and recovery. Those are the ones who despair of the Hereafter [al-Ākhira], just as the disbelievers despair of the companions of the graves. And this is the meaning of the heart's [al-qalb] blackening by sins, as the Qur'an and the Sunnah have articulated.

a.g: Those cities - We relate to you, [O Muhammad], some of their news. And certainly did their messengers come to them with clear proofs, but they were not to believe in that which they had denied before. Thus does Allah seal over the hearts of the disbelievers.
And We did not find for most of them any covenant; but indeed, We found most of them defiantly disobedient.
Then We sent after them Moses with Our signs to Pharaoh and his establishment, but they were unjust toward them. So see how was the end of the corrupters.
And Moses said, "O Pharaoh, I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds
[Who is] obligated not to say about Allah except the truth. I have come to you with clear evidence from your Lord, so send with me the Children of Israel."
[Pharaoh] said, "If you have come with a sign, then bring it forth, if you should be of the truthful."
So Moses threw his staff, and suddenly it was a serpent, manifest.
And he drew out his hand; thereupon it was white [with radiance] for the observers.
Said the eminent among the people of Pharaoh, "Indeed, this is a learned magician
Who wants to expel you from your land [through magic], so what do you instruct?"
They said, "Postpone [the matter of] him and his brother and send among the cities gatherers
Who will bring you every learned magician."
And the magicians came to Pharaoh. They said, "Indeed for us is a reward if we are the predominant."
He said, "Yes, and, [moreover], you will be among those made near [to me]."
They said, "O Moses, either you throw [your staff], or we will be the ones to throw [first]."
He said, "Throw," and when they threw, they bewitched the eyes of the people and struck terror into them, and they presented a great [feat of] magic.
And We inspired to Moses, "Throw your staff," and at once it devoured what they were falsifying.
So the truth was established, and abolished was what they were doing.
And Pharaoh and his people were overcome right there and became debased.
And the magicians fell down in prostration [to Allah].
They said, "We have believed in the Lord of the worlds,
The Lord of Moses and Aaron."
Said Pharaoh, "You believed in him before I gave you permission. Indeed, this is a conspiracy which you conspired in the city to expel therefrom its people. But you are going to know.
I will surely cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides; then I will surely crucify you all."
They said, "Indeed, to our Lord we will return.
And you do not resent us except because we believed in the signs of our Lord when they came to us. Our Lord, pour upon us patience and let us die as Muslims [in submission to You]."

And the eminent among the people of Pharaoh said," Will you leave Moses and his people to cause corruption in the land and abandon you and your gods?" [Pharaoh] said, "We will kill their sons and keep their women alive; and indeed, we are subjugators over them."

Said Moses to his people, "Seek help through Allah and be patient. Indeed, the earth belongs to Allah. He causes to inherit it whom He wills of His servants. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous."

They said, "We have been harmed before you came to us and after you have come to us." He said, "Perhaps your Lord will destroy your enemy and grant you succession in the land and see how you will do."
And We certainly seized the people of Pharaoh with years of famine and a deficiency in fruits that perhaps they would be reminded.

But when good came to them, they said, "This is ours [by right]." And if a bad [condition] struck them, they saw an evil omen in Moses and those with him. Unquestionably, their fortune is with Allah, but most of them do not know.
And they said, "No matter what sign you bring us with which to bewitch us, we will not be believers in you."
So We sent upon them the flood and locusts and lice and frogs and blood as distinct signs, but they were arrogant and were a criminal people.

And when the punishment descended upon them, they said, "O Moses, invoke for us your Lord by what He has promised you. If you [can] remove the punishment from us, we will surely believe you, and we will send with you the Children of Israel."
But when We removed the punishment from them until a term which they were to reach, then at once they broke their word.
So We took retribution from them, and We drowned them in the sea because they denied Our signs and were heedless of them.

And We caused the people who had been oppressed to inherit the eastern regions of the land and the western ones, which We had blessed. And the good word of your Lord was fulfilled for the Children of Israel because of what they had patiently endured. And We destroyed [all] that Pharaoh and his people were producing and what they had been building.

Indeed, the Most High has said: "And the good word [al-kalimah al-husna] of your Lord was fulfilled for the Children of Israel because of what they patiently endured [sabarū]." Thus, there is no act of worship [qurbah] except that its reward is by measure and calculation, except for patience [al-sabr].

a.g: And We took the Children of Israel across the sea; then they came upon a people intent in devotion to [some] idols of theirs. They said, "O Moses, make for us a god just as they have gods." He said, "Indeed, you are a people behaving ignorantly.
Indeed, those [worshippers] - destroyed is that in which they are [engaged], and worthless is whatever they were doing."
He said, "Is it other than Allah I should desire for you as a god while He has preferred you over the worlds?"

And [recall, O Children of Israel], when We saved you from the people of Pharaoh, [who were] afflicting you with the worst torment - killing your sons and keeping your women alive. And in that was a great trial from your Lord.

And We made an appointment with Moses for thirty nights and perfected them by [the addition of] ten; so the term of his Lord was completed as forty nights. And Moses said to his brother Aaron, "Take my place among my people, do right [by them], and do not follow the way of the corrupters."

And when Moses arrived at Our appointed time and his Lord spoke to him, he said, "My Lord, show me [Yourself] that I may look at You." [Allah] said, "You will not see Me, but look at the mountain; if it should remain in place, then you will see Me." But when his Lord appeared to the mountain, He rendered it level, and Moses fell unconscious. And when he awoke, he said, "Exalted are You! I have repented to You, and I am the first of the believers."

And the correct position is that the Messenger of God, may God bless him and grant him peace, did not see God, the Most High, on the Night of the Ascension [laylat al-miʿrāj].

a.g: [Allah] said, "O Moses, I have chosen you over the people with My messages and My words [to you]. So take what I have given you and be among the grateful."

And We wrote for him on the tablets [something] of all things - instruction and explanation for all things, [saying], "Take them with determination and order your people to take the best of it. I will show you the home of the defiantly disobedient."

I will turn away from My signs those who are arrogant upon the earth without right; and if they should see every sign, they will not believe in it. And if they see the way of consciousness, they will not adopt it as a way; but if they see the way of error, they will adopt it as a way. That is because they have denied Our signs and they were heedless of them.

a.g: Those who denied Our signs and the meeting of the Hereafter - their deeds have become worthless. Are they recompensed except for what they used to do?

And the people of Moses made, after [his departure], from their ornaments a calf - an image having a lowing sound. Did they not see that it could neither speak to them nor guide them to a way? They took it [for worship], and they were wrongdoers.
And when regret overcame them and they saw that they had gone astray, they said, "If our Lord does not have mercy upon us and forgive us, we will surely be among the losers."

And when Moses returned to his people, angry and grieved, he said, "How wretched is that by which you have replaced me after [my departure]. Were you impatient over the matter of your Lord?" And he threw down the tablets and seized his brother by [the hair of] his head, pulling him toward him. [Aaron] said, "O son of my mother, indeed the people oppressed me and were about to kill me, so let not the enemies rejoice over me and do not place me among the wrongdoing people."
[Moses] said, "My Lord, forgive me and my brother and admit us into Your mercy, for You are the most merciful of the merciful."
Indeed, those who took the calf [for worship] will obtain anger from their Lord and humiliation in the life of this world, and thus do We recompense the inventors [of falsehood].
But those who committed misdeeds and then repented after them and believed - indeed your Lord, thereafter, is Forgiving and Merciful.
And when the anger subsided in Moses, he took up the tablets; and in their inscription was guidance and mercy for those who are fearful of their Lord.

And Moses chose from his people seventy men for Our appointment. And when the earthquake seized them, he said, "My Lord, if You had willed, You could have destroyed them before and me [as well]. Would You destroy us for what the foolish among us have done? This is not but Your trial by which You send astray whom You will and guide whom You will. You are our Protector, so forgive us and have mercy upon us; and You are the best of forgivers.

Indeed, likewise, expansion [al-inbisat] and intimate boldness [al-idlal] are permissible for some worshippers, but not for others. And from the expansion of intimate familiarity [al-uns] is the saying of Musa, peace be upon him: "It is nothing but Your trial [fitnatuka]—You cause to stray with it whom You will and You guide with it whom You will."

a.g: And decree for us in this world [that which is] good and [also] in the Hereafter; indeed, we have turned back to You." [Allah] said, "My punishment - I afflict with it whom I will, but My mercy encompasses all things." So I will decree it [especially] for those who fear Me and give zakah and those who believe in Our verses -

Those who follow the Messenger, the unlettered prophet, whom they find written in what they have of the Torah and the Gospel, who enjoins upon them what is right and forbids them what is wrong and makes lawful for them the good things and prohibits for them the evil and relieves them of their burden and the shackles which were upon them. So they who have believed in him, honored him, supported him and followed the light which was sent down with him - it is those who will be the successful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Indeed, the Most High says: "And He relieves them of their burden [isr] and the shackles [aghlal] which were upon them." And what indicates its meaning is the response of God, the Most High, to the believers in their saying: "And do not place upon us a burden [isr]." And He, peace be upon him, said: "I was sent with the easy, tolerant, lenient monotheism [al-hanifiyyah al-samhah al-sahlah]." And He, peace be upon him, said to every chosen servant [abd mustafa]: "I love that the people of the two Books know that in our religion there is tolerance [samahah]."

a.g: Say, [O Muhammad], "O mankind, indeed I am the Messenger of Allah to you all, [from Him] to whom belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. There is no deity except Him; He gives life and causes death." So believe in Allah and His Messenger, the unlettered prophet, who believes in Allah and His words, and follow him that you may be guided.
And among the people of Moses is a community which guides by truth and by it establishes justice.

And We divided them into twelve descendant tribes [as distinct] nations. And We inspired to Moses when his people implored him for water, "Strike with your staff the stone," and there gushed forth from it twelve springs. Every people knew its watering place. And We shaded them with clouds and sent down upon them manna and quails, [saying], "Eat from the good things with which We have provided you." And they wronged Us not, but they were [only] wronging themselves.

And [mention, O Muhammad], when it was said to them, "Dwell in this city and eat from it wherever you will and say, 'Relieve us of our burdens,' and enter the gate bowing humbly; We will [then] forgive you your sins. We will increase the doers of good [in goodness and reward]."
But those who wronged among them changed [the words] to a statement other than that which had been said to them. So We sent upon them a punishment from the sky for the wrong that they were doing.

And ask them about the town that was by the sea - when they transgressed in [the matter of] the sabbath - when their fish came to them openly on their sabbath day, and the day they had no sabbath they did not come to them. Thus did We give them trial because they were defiantly disobedient.

And when a community among them said, "Why do you advise [or warn] a people whom Allah is [about] to destroy or to punish with a severe punishment?" they [the advisors] said, "To be absolved before your Lord and perhaps they may fear Him."
And when they forgot that by which they had been reminded, We saved those who had forbidden evil and seized those who wronged, with a wretched punishment, because they were defiantly disobeying.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k09
Indeed, when they forgot what they had been reminded of, We saved those who forbade the evil [as-su'] and seized those who did wrong [zalamu] with a wretched punishment for their defiant disobedience. Thus, He made clear that they attained salvation through forbidding the evil [an-nahy 'an as-su'], and this also indicates its obligation [al-wujub].

a.g: So when they were insolent about that which they had been forbidden, We said to them, "Be apes, despised."

And [mention] when your Lord declared that He would surely [continue to] send upon them until the Day of Resurrection those who would afflict them with the worst torment. Indeed, your Lord is swift in penalty; but indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful.

And We divided them throughout the earth into nations. Of them some were righteous, and of them some were otherwise. And We tested them with good [times] and bad that perhaps they would return [to obedience].

And there followed them successors who inherited the Scripture [while] taking the commodities of this lower life and saying, "It will be forgiven for us." And if an offer like it comes to them, they will [again] take it. Was not the covenant of the Scripture taken from them that they would not say about Allah except the truth, and they studied what was in it? And the home of the Hereafter is better for those who fear Allah, so will you not use reason?
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 10a
Indeed, if one scatters seed in hard, barren, elevated ground where water does not flow, and does not engage in tending the seed at all, then expects a harvest from it, his expectation is called folly [ḥamq] and delusion [ghurūr], not hope [rajāʾ]... So, the servant [al-ʿabd], when he scatters the seed of faith [īmān] and waters it with the water of acts of obedience [ṭāʿāt], and purifies the heart [qalb] from the thorns of vile character traits [akhlāq], and awaits from the grace of God, the Exalted, His making him steadfast in that until death and a good ending [ḥusn al-khātimah] leading to forgiveness [maghfirah], then his awaiting is a true, praiseworthy hope [rajāʾ] in itself, spurring him to persevere in fulfilling the requisites of the causes of faith [īmān] in completing the causes of forgiveness [maghfirah] until death. But if he ceases to tend the seed of faith [īmān] with the water of acts of obedience [ṭāʿāt] and leaves the heart [qalb] laden with base character traits [akhlāq], and immerses himself in seeking the pleasures of the lower world [dunyā], then expects forgiveness [maghfirah], his expectation is folly [ḥamq] and delusion [ghurūr]... And God, the Exalted, said: "Then there succeeded after them a succession who inherited the Scripture, taking the merchandise of this lower life [al-dunyā] and saying, 'It will be forgiven for us.'"... As for one who immerses himself in what God, the Exalted, dislikes and does not censure himself for it, nor resolves upon repentance [tawbah] and return, his hope [rajāʾ] for forgiveness [maghfirah] is folly [ḥamq], like the hope [rajāʾ] of one who scatters seed in barren ground and resolves not to tend it with watering or purification.

a.g: But those who hold fast to the Book and establish prayer - indeed, We will not allow to be lost the reward of the reformers.

And [mention] when We raised the mountain above them as if it was a dark cloud and they were certain that it would fall upon them, [and Allah said], "Take what We have given you with determination and remember what is in it that you might fear Allah."

And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying to them], "Am I not your Lord?" They said, "Yes, we have testified." [This] - lest you should say on the day of Resurrection, "Indeed, we were of this unaware."

Or [lest] you say, "It was only that our fathers associated [others in worship] with Allah before, and we were but descendants after them. Then would You destroy us for what the falsifiers have done?"
And thus do We [explain in] detail the verses, and perhaps they will return.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, if you ask them who created them, they will say, "Allah." (Its meaning is that if you consider their states, their very souls [nafs] and their innermost beings [batin] bear witness to that by the primordial nature [fitra] of Allah upon which He created mankind—meaning, every human is created upon faith [iman] in Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, nay, upon the knowledge [ma'rifa] of things as they truly are, meaning that they are as if embedded within them due to the readiness of their preparedness for perception. Then, since faith is firmly rooted in the souls [nafs] by primordial nature [fitra], people became divided into two groups: those who turned away and thus forgot—and they are the disbelievers—and those who turned over their thoughts and thus remembered, so they became like one who carried a testimony but forgot it through heedlessness, then remembered it. And for that reason, He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "That they might remember," "That those of understanding might remember," "And remember the favor of Allah upon you and His covenant with which He bound you," and "And We have certainly made the Qur'an easy for remembrance; so is there any who will remember?" Naming this mode 'remembrance' is not far-fetched, for it is as if remembrance [tadhakkur] is of two kinds: one is that he remembers a form that was present in existence in his heart [qalb] but became absent after the other existence.)

a.g: And recite to them, [O Muhammad], the news of him to whom we gave [knowledge of] Our signs, but he detached himself from them; so Satan pursued him, and he became of the deviators.

So his example is like that of the dog: if you chase him, he pants, or if you leave him, he [still] pants. That is the example of the people who denied Our signs. So relate the stories that perhaps they will give thought.

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, whoever deviates from this path [tariqa] is like the one concerning whom Allah, the Most High, said: "Have you seen he who has taken his desire [hawa] as his god, and Allah has led him astray despite knowledge [‘ilm]?" And He, the Most High, said: "And he followed his desire [hawa]; so his likeness is as the likeness of a dog: if you attack it, it pants, or if you leave it, it pants." Indeed, the one who knows chess, when he sees a player making a mistake, cannot remain silent from instruction, and his tongue flows with mentioning what he knows. All of that is due to the intensity of the pleasure of knowledge [‘ilm] and what he senses of the perfection of his own essence through it. For knowledge [‘ilm] is among the most specific attributes of Lordship [rububiyya], and it is the ultimate perfection. Therefore, the nature [tab’] finds comfort when praised for intelligence and abundance of knowledge [‘ilm], because upon hearing the praise, he senses the perfection of his essence and the perfection of his knowledge [‘ilm], so he admires himself and delights in it. Then, the pleasure of knowledge [‘ilm] of farming and tailoring is not like the pleasure of knowledge [‘ilm] of governing a kingdom and managing the affairs of creation. Nor is the pleasure of knowledge [‘ilm] of grammar and poetry like the pleasure of knowledge [‘ilm] of God, Exalted is He, and His attributes, His angels, and the dominion [mulk] of the heavens and the earth. Rather, the pleasure of knowledge [‘ilm] is according to the nobility of the knowledge [‘ilm], and the nobility of the knowledge [‘ilm] is according to the nobility of the known [ma’lum]. So much so that the one who knows the inner states [bawatin ahwal] of people and informs of it finds a pleasure in it, even if his ignorance compels his nature [tab’] to investigate it. If he knows the inner states [bawatin ahwal] of the city's leader and the secrets of his management in his leadership, that is more pleasurable and sweeter to him than knowing the inner state [batin hal] of a farmer or a weaver. If he becomes aware of the secrets of the minister and his management and what he is resolved upon in the affairs of the ministry, that is more desirable and pleasurable to him than his knowledge [‘ilm] of the secrets of the leader. If he is knowledgeable of the inner states [bawatin ahwal] of the king and the sultan who is the sovereign, that is sweeter and more pleasurable to him than his knowledge [‘ilm] of the inner secrets of the minister. And his boasting of that, his eagerness for it, his investigation into it, and his love for it would be greater, because his pleasure in it is greater. Through this, it becomes clear that the most pleasurable of knowledges [ma’arif] are the noblest of them, and their nobility is according to the nobility of the known [ma’lum]. If among the known things [ma’lumat] there is that which is the most majestic, the most complete, the noblest, and the greatest, then knowledge [‘ilm] of it is, without doubt, the most pleasurable of knowledges [‘ulum], the noblest of them, and the sweetest of them. I wonder, is there in existence anything more majestic, higher, nobler, more complete, and greater than the Creator of all things, their Perfecter, their Adorner, their Originator, their Restorer, their Manager, and their Arranger? And can it be conceived that there is a presence [hadra] in sovereignty [mulk], perfection [kamal], beauty [jamal], splendor [baha’], and majesty [jalal] greater than the Divine Presence [al-hadra al-rabbaniyya], whose beginnings of majesty [jalaha] and wonders of its states [ahwal] the descriptors cannot encompass? If you do not doubt that, then you should not doubt that becoming aware of the secrets of Lordship [rububiyya] and knowledge [‘ilm] of the arrangement of the Divine affairs encompassing all existents is the highest of the types of knowledges [ma’arif] and awarenesses, the most pleasurable of them, the sweetest of them, and the most desirable of them? It is the most deserving thing by which the souls [nufus] sense their perfection [kamal] and their beauty [jamal] when being qualified by it, and the most worthy thing by which joy, comfort, and gladness are magnified. And through this, it becomes clear that knowledge [‘ilm] is pleasurable, and that the most pleasurable of knowledges [‘ulum] is knowledge [‘ilm] of God, Exalted is He, and His attributes, His actions, and His management in His dominion [mamlakati]—from the utmost limit of His Throne to the depths of the earths. Therefore, it should be known that the pleasure of knowledge [ma’rifa] is stronger than all other pleasures—I mean the pleasure of appetites [shahawat] and anger, and the pleasure of the rest of the five senses. For the pleasures differ in type firstly, like the difference between the pleasure of intercourse and the pleasure of hearing, and the pleasure of knowledge [ma’rifa] and the pleasure of leadership. Indeed, among the strongest incitements to anger [ghadab] for most of the ignorant is their naming of anger as courage [shaja'a], manliness, self-respect ['izzat nafs], and high ambition, and their labeling it with praiseworthy titles—this is foolishness and ignorance, until the soul [nafs] inclines towards it and approves of it. This can be reinforced by recounting the intensity of anger from great figures in the context of praising courage, and souls [nufus] are inclined to emulate great figures, so anger is stirred in the heart [qalb] because of it. To name this self-respect and courage is ignorance; rather, it is a sickness of the heart [qalb] and a deficiency of intellect ['aql], and it is due to the weakness and deficiency of the soul [nafs]. A sign that it is from the weakness of the soul [nafs] is that the sick person is quicker to anger than the healthy, the woman is quicker to anger than the man, the child is quicker to anger than the grown man, the weak old man is quicker to anger than the middle-aged man, and the one with bad character and vile traits is quicker to anger than the possessor of virtues. Thus, the vile person becomes angry for his desire [shahwa] if a morsel escapes him, and for his miserliness if a grain escapes him, to the point that he becomes angry with his family, his children, and his companions. Rather, the strong one is he who controls himself during anger, as the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "The strong is not the one who overcomes people by his strength. Rather, the strong is the one who controls himself while in anger." Rather, this ignorant one should be treated by reciting to him the accounts of the people of forbearance [hilm] and pardon ['afw], and what was deemed good from them in suppressing rage [ghayz], for that is transmitted from the Prophets, the saints [awliya'], the wise, the scholars, and the great, virtuous kings. And the opposite of that is transmitted from the Kurds, the Turks, the ignorant, and the foolish who have no intellects and no virtue in them. **Explanation of Treating Anger After Its Agitation** What we have mentioned is the severing of the sources of anger and the cutting off of its causes so that it does not stir. If a cause for its agitation occurs, then at that point one must be deliberate so that its owner is not compelled to act upon it in the blameworthy manner. Anger, when agitated, is only treated with the compound of knowledge ['ilm] and action ['amal]. As for knowledge ['ilm], it is six matters: **The First:** That he reflects upon the reports we will present regarding the virtue of suppressing rage [ghayz], pardon ['afw], forbearance [hilm], and endurance, so he desires its reward. Thus, the intensity of his craving for the reward of suppression prevents him from seeking satisfaction and revenge, and his rage [ghayz] is extinguished. Malik bin Aws bin Al-Hadthan said: "Umar became angry with a man and ordered him to be struck. I said, 'O Commander of the Faithful, *"Hold to forgiveness; enjoin what is good; and turn away from the ignorant."*' So Umar would say, *'Hold to forgiveness; enjoin what is good; and turn away from the ignorant,'* and he would contemplate the verse, and he was one who halted at the Book of God. Whenever it was recited to him, he would ponder over it greatly. So he pondered over it and released the man."

Rather, the strong is the one who controls himself while in anger." Rather, this ignorant one should be treated by reciting to him the accounts of the people of forbearance [hilm] and pardon ['afw], and what was deemed good from them in suppressing rage [ghayz], for that is transmitted from the Prophets, the saints [awliya'], the wise, the scholars, and the great, virtuous kings. If a cause for its agitation occurs, then at that point one must be deliberate so that its owner is not compelled to act upon it in the blameworthy manner. Anger, when agitated, is only treated with the compound of knowledge ['ilm] and action ['amal]. As for knowledge ['ilm], it is six matters: **The First:** That he reflects upon the reports we will present regarding the virtue of suppressing rage [ghayz], pardon ['afw], forbearance [hilm], and endurance, so he desires its reward. Malik bin Aws bin Al-Hadthan said: "Umar became angry with a man and ordered him to be struck. I said, 'O Commander of the Faithful, *"Hold to forgiveness; enjoin what is good; and turn away from the ignorant."*' So Umar would say, *'Hold to forgiveness; enjoin what is good; and turn away from the ignorant,'* and he would contemplate the verse, and he was one who halted at the Book of God. Whenever it was recited to him, he would ponder over it greatly. So he pondered over it and released the man."

a.g: Indeed, those who fear Allah - when an impulse touches them from Satan, they remember [Him] and at once they have insight.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book2a
Indeed, O you who have believed, fear Allah [ittaqū Allāh] and let a soul [nafs] look to what it has sent forth for tomorrow. And this is an indication to the reckoning [muḥāsaba] concerning what has passed of deeds. And for that reason, 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Reckon with your souls [ḥāsibū anfusakum] before you are reckoned with, and weigh them before they are weighed." And He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, those who fear Allah [ittaqaw] – when an impulse from Satan touches them, they remember [dhakkarū] and at once they have insight [mubṣirūn]." And from 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, is that he would strike his feet with a whip when night covered him and say to his soul [nafs]: "What have you done today?" And from Maimūn ibn Mihrān is that he said: "The servant [ʿabd] is not among those who fear Allah [al-muttaqīn] until he reckons with his soul [yuḥāsiba nafsahu] more severely than the reckoning of his partner, and the two partners reckon with each other after the work."

a.g: But their brothers - the devils increase them in error; then they do not stop short.

And when you, [O Muhammad], do not bring them a sign, they say, "Why have you not contrived it?" Say, "I only follow what is revealed to me from my Lord. This [Qur'an] is enlightenment from your Lord and guidance and mercy for a people who believe."
So when the Qur'an is recited, then listen to it and pay attention that you may receive mercy.
And remember your Lord within yourself in humility and in fear without being apparent in speech - in the mornings and the evenings. And do not be among the heedless.

And remember your Lord [Rabb] within your soul [nafs], in humility [tadarru'] and fear [khawf], and without loudness in speech, in the morning and the evening, and do not be among the heedless [ghafilun].
